functions.name: search
functions.desc: Search Wikipedia for an article with the given title, and get its content. If no such article is found, return similar article names.

msg.content: How many countries can the top 5 strongest passport holders travel to in 2023?

msg.name: search

msg.content:
<document>
<title>Henley Passport Index</title>
<fragment>

As of 8 September 2023, the Singaporean passport offers holders visa-free or visa-on-arrival access to a total of 193 countries and territories, followed by the Finnish, French, German, Italian, Japanese, South Korean, Spanish and Swedish passports, each offering 190 visa-free or visa-on-arrival countries and territories to its holders. These rankings were subsequently followed by the Austrian, Danish, Irish, Luxembourgeois and British passports, each offering visa-free or visa-on-arrival travel to 189 countries and territories.


An Afghan passport has once again been labelled by the index as the least powerful passport in the world, with its nationals only able to visit 27 destinations visa-free.[20][21] This was followed by the Iraqi passport at 29 destinations and the Syrian passport at 30 destinations.[22]






</fragment>
<fragment>

1. **^** Moore, Cortney (20 July 2022). "American passports rank as 7th most powerful, travel index says". *Fox News*.
2. **^** Smith, Oliver (29 February 2016). "The world's most powerful passports". *The Telegraph*. Archived from the original on 23 February 2017. Retrieved 21 July 2018.
3. ^ ***a*** ***b*** Lmahamad, Ayya (11 January 2023). "Azerbaijan improves its position in World Passport Index". *Azer News*.
4. **^** Andrejevic, Mark and Volcic, Zala (2016). *Commercial Nationalism: Selling the Nation and Nationalizing the Sell*. Palgrave Macmillan, New York. ISBN 9781137500984
5. **^** Neammanee, Pocharapon; Lee, Lloyd (20 July 2022). "The most powerful passports in the world in 2022, ranked". *Insider Inc.* Retrieved 28 August 2022.
6. **^** "How powerful is your country's passport in 2023?". *Quartz*. 24 January 2023.
7. **^** Abrahamian, Atossa Araxia (2015). *The Cosmopolites: The Coming of the Global Citizen*, pp. 70–93. Colombia Global Reports, New York. ISBN 9780990976363

</fragment>
<fragment>
8. **^** Dannielle Maguire (15 January 2023). "Australian passports are among the world's most powerful. So where can it take you?". *ABC News*.
9. **^** Gleeson, Colin (19 July 2022). "Irish passport ranked joint sixth most powerful globally". *The Irish Times*. Retrieved 28 August 2022.
10. **^** Fernandez, Celia. "Japan has the No. 1 most powerful passport in the world for 2023—see where the U.S. lands on the list". *CNBC*.
11. **^** "How powerful is the Indian passport? Check out Henley Index ranking". *Zee Business*. 22 May 2018. Retrieved 28 August 2022.
12. **^** McDonagh, Shannon (31 January 2022). "These are the world's most powerful passports in 2022". *Euronews*. Retrieved 28 August 2022.
13. **^** Neammanee, Pocharapon (28 July 2022). "The Most Powerful Passports in the World in 2022, Ranked". *Entrepreneur magazine*.
14. **^** "Pakistani passport remains fourth-worst in the world: Henley index". *Dawn (newspaper)*. 20 July 2022.

</fragment>
<fragment>
21. **^** "Henley Passport Index: World most powerful passports ranking for 2023". *BBC*. 10 January 2023.
22. **^** "Henley Passport Index:The World's Most Powerful Passports in 2023". 19 July 2023.
23. **^** Whitley, Angus. "Europe once offered the world's most powerful passports. Not anymore". *Fortune*. Retrieved 28 August 2022.
24. **^** "The World's Most Powerful Passports in 2022". *OnlineVisa*.
25. **^** "Canadian Passport Ranked Eighth Most Powerful In World - Canada Immigration and Visa Information. Canadian Immigration Services and Free Online Evaluation". Canadian Citizenship & Immigration Resource Center. 21 July 2022.
26. **^** Madden, Duncan (10 January 2020). "The Most Powerful Passports In The World In 2020". *Forbes*. Archived from the original on 10 January 2020. Retrieved 11 January 2020.
27. ^ ***a*** ***b*** "Henley Passport Index". *Henley Passport Index*. Archived from the original on 15 January 2022. Retrieved 15 January 2022.

</fragment>
<fragment>

As of 2022, a Japanese passport offers its holders visa-free or visa-on-arrival access to a total of 193 countries and territories, with South Korean and Singapore passports each offering 192 visa-free or visa-on-arrival countries and territories to their holders.[23][24] An American passport offers its holders visa-free or visa-on-arrival access to 186 countries and territories, with the British passport offering 187 visa-free or visa-on-arrival countries and territories to their holders. Canadian and Australian passports each offer their holders visa-free access to 185 countries and territories.[25]


An Afghan passport has once again been labelled by the index as the least powerful passport in the world, with its nationals only able to visit 27 destinations visa-free.[26]






</fragment>
<fragment>
15. **^** Kalin, Christian H. (2015). *Global Residence and Citizenship Handbook* (5 ed.). Ideos Publications. pp. 147–148. ISBN 978-3-9524052-7-7.
16. **^** Kalin, Christian H. (2015). *Global Residence and Citizenship Handbook* (5 ed.). Ideos Publications. pp. 148–149. ISBN 978-3-9524052-7-7.
17. **^** "Henley Passport Index 2006 to 2018". *Henley & Partners Passport Index*. Henley & Partners Holdings Ltd. Archived from the original on 9 July 2018. Retrieved 7 July 2018. The index and its contents are based on data provided by the International Air Transport Authority (IATA) and supplemented, enhanced, and updated using extensive in-house research and open-source online data.
18. **^** O'Hare, Maureen (19 July 2022). "The world's most powerful passports for 2022". *CNN*.
19. **^** Klawans, Justin. "10 of the world's most powerful passports". *The Week*.
20. **^** "Italy's New Luxury Hotels, The Most Powerful Passports, Delta's Free Wifi And More". *Forbes*.

</fragment>
<fragment>
5. Where visas are needed, or where passport holders must get government-approved electronic visas (e-Visas) before departure, a score of 0 is given. If passport holders must get government approval before leaving in order to obtain a visa on arrival, this also scores 0.
6. The score for each passport is then totalled by adding up its scores for all destinations.[17]
7. The index ignores temporary restrictions or airspace closures.[18]
8. It considers mobility data based on national GDPs and the percentage of global wealth that the country's passport could provide access to.[19]


## Rankings[edit]


### 2023 Henley Passport Index[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>
| 2023rank | Passport issuing country | Visa-freedestinations
 |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1
 | ![](image) Singapore | 193 |
| 2
 | ![](image) Japan | 191 |
| 3
 | ![](image) Finland | 190 |
| ![](image) France | 190 |
| ![](image) Germany | 190 |
| ![](image) Italy | 190 |
| ![](image) South Korea | 190 |
| ![](image) Spain | 190 |
| ![](image) Sweden | 190 |
| 4 | ![](image) Austria | 189 |
| ![](image) Denmark | 189 |
| ![](image) Ireland | 189 |
| ![](image) Luxembourg | 189 |
| ![](image) Netherlands | 189 |
| ![](image) United Kingdom | 189 |
| 5 | ![](image) Belgium | 188 |
| ![](image) Malta | 188 |
| ![](image) Portugal | 188 |
| ![](image) Norway | 188 |
| 6
 | ![](image) Czech Republic | 187 |
| ![](image) New Zealand | 187 |
| ![](image) Poland | 187 |
| ![](image)  Switzerland | 187 |
| 7
 | ![](image) Australia | 186 |
| ![](image) Canada | 186 |
| ![](image) Greece | 186 |
| ![](image) Hungary | 186 |
| ![](image) United States | 186 |
| 8
 | ![](image) Lithuania | 185 |
| 9

</fragment>
<fragment>
| 2022rank[27] | Passport issuing country | Visa-freedestinations
 |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1
 | ![](image) Japan | 193 |
| 2 | ![](image) Singapore | 192 |
| ![](image) South Korea | 192 |
| 4 | ![](image) Germany | 190 |
| ![](image) Spain | 190 |
| 6 | ![](image) Finland | 189 |
| ![](image) Italy | 189 |
| ![](image) Luxembourg | 189 |
| 9 | ![](image) Austria | 188 |
| ![](image) Denmark | 188 |
| ![](image) Netherlands | 188 |
| ![](image) Sweden | 188 |
| 13 | ![](image) France | 187 |
| ![](image) Ireland | 187 |
| ![](image) Portugal | 187 |
| ![](image) United Kingdom | 187 |
| 17 | ![](image) Belgium | 186 |
| ![](image) New Zealand | 186 |
| ![](image) Norway | 186 |
| ![](image)  Switzerland | 186 |
| ![](image) United States | 186 |
| 22 | ![](image) Australia | 185 |
| ![](image) Canada | 185 |
| ![](image) Czech Republic | 185 |
| ![](image) Greece | 185 |
| ![](image) Malta | 185 |
| 27 | ![](image) Hungary | 183 |
| 28 | ![](image) Lithuania | 182 |
| ![](image) Poland | 182 |

</fragment>
<fragment>

The index annually ranks 199 passports of the world by the number of countries that their holders can travel to without visas.[5] The number of countries that a specific passport can access becomes its visa-free "score". In collaboration with the International Air Transport Association (IATA),[6] and using official data from their global database, Henley & Partners has analysed the visa regulations of almost all the world's countries and territories since 2006.[3][7]




## Definition of the Index[edit]


The Henley Passport index (HPI) ranks passports according to the number of destinations that can be reached using a particular country's ordinary passport without the need of a prior visa ("visa-free").[8][9] The survey ranks 199 passports against 227 destination[10] countries, territories, and micro-states.[11][12][13]


</fragment>
</document>

msg.name: search

msg.content:
Based on the Henley Passport Index for 2023, the top 5 strongest passports and the number of countries they can travel to without a visa or with visa-on-arrival are as follows:

1. **Singapore**: 193 countries
2. **Japan**: 191 countries
3. **Finland, France, Germany, Italy, South Korea, Spain, Sweden**: 190 countries each

So, the top 5 strongest passport holders can travel to the following number of countries:

1. **Singapore**: 193 countries
2. **Japan**: 191 countries
3. **Finland**: 190 countries
4. **France**: 190 countries
5. **Germany**: 190 countries

This means the top 5 strongest passport holders can travel to between 190 and 193 countries in 2023.

Based on the Henley Passport Index for 2023, the top 5 strongest passports and the number of countries they can travel to without a visa or with visa-on-arrival are as follows:

1. **Singapore**: 193 countries
2. **Japan**: 191 countries
3. **Finland, France, Germany, Italy, South Korea, Spain, Sweden**: 190 countries each

So, the top 5 strongest passport holders can travel to the following number of countries:

1. **Singapore**: 193 countries
2. **Japan**: 191 countries
3. **Finland**: 190 countries
4. **France**: 190 countries
5. **Germany**: 190 countries

This means the top 5 strongest passport holders can travel to between 190 and 193 countries in 2023.
